I sent the following letter resigning my 15 year APA membership in 2007 after the initial allegations regarding torture emerged. It now appears APA's behavior was far worse than I could have imagined.

Dear APA,

I have been a proud member of APA for over 15 years. At the APA convention in August, I was appalled by APA’s decision to continue to allow psychologists to collude with our government’s torture of detainees in Guantanamo, Cuba.

I had the good fortune to attend the International Psychoanalytic Association conference in Berlin this summer. This was the first time the conference had been held in Berlin since Hitler came to power. At the conference, many psychologists movingly described the still palpable effects of genocide, torture, and totalitarianism on the Nazi’s victims. Evil on such scale required the collusion of a large part of the populace. As psychologists, we bear a special responsibility confront such collusion within ourselves, our patients and our nation. I will not allow my dues to be used to collude with our government’s immoral treatment of other human beings. Therefore, I am withholding my dues until APA clearly and unequivocally forbids psychologists’ collusion with torture. I will not allow the APA to speak for me when it turns a blind eye to torture.

We must name this evil and confront it now. If not now, when?

This is not so much an issue of 'truth' or 'lies' in photography as an issue of integrity or dishonesty amongst practitioners. I think we must draw a clear line between these two issues. A photo can be 'truthful' in what it depicts, but also aid & abet a lie when used thus by a liar.

That images don't tell a 'whole' truth is a given, we have no idea what was outside the frame when it was taken, nor how what was included actually got there - whether by accident or design. But we should be able to trust the taker to reflect the accuracy of the story of the content that WAS captured.

I think we must also draw a distinct line between 'editorial publication' and the process of curation that leads to that image use, AND entry into a competition.

The 'rules' for competitions are variable, with different standards across the board. And it is a fact that journalistic images that were successfully published in the media as suitably representing issues were later disqualified from a photojournalism competition for being 'untruthful' - untruthful in the way the image content was altered and was perceived to have been deliberately manipulated. From that conclusion some proclaim faith in the equation: manipulation = deception. It is rarely that straightforward.

You might conclude from that, that there are higher standards being upheld in competitions. I dont think this is the case. They are just different standards with closer scrutiny.

Personal integrity is the real issue.
